title: There’s a storm brewing Australia
text:
GET ready Australia. There’s a cracker of storm heading for the east coast with thunder, large hailstones and damaging winds on the menu. 
And NSW and southeast Queensland are expected to cop the brunt of mother nature’s carnage. 
The bureau of meteorology has issued a top priority, immediate warning covering New South Wales’ northern rivers, mid north coast and northern tablelands districts to expect severe thunderstorms in the next few hours. 
Queenslanders in the south east of the state, including Brisbane, can also expect a rough ride home, with storms set to hit throughout the afternoon. 
In NSW Grafton, Kempsey, Casino, Kyogle, Tabulam and Dorrigo are all in the firing line. 
There’s also marine wind warnings current for the Hunter, Sydney and Illawarra coasts and a strong wind warning for the Byron Coast, Batemans Coast and Eden Coast. 
Olenka Duma, forecaster at the Bureau of Meteorology told news.com.au the storms were mostly around the northern part of the state. 
“We have a low pressure trough moving through the state it’s bringing some thunderstorms. 
“We do have some (thunder) strikes currently over the Hunter and Northern regions with the majority over the northern tablelands northern rivers, mid north coast,” she said. 
“We currently have a severe thunderstorm warning out. 
“That's for damaging winds and large hail stones.” 
She said most of the storm was expected to move north and clear later tonight. While Sydney still had remnant showers from yesterday the Bureau was not expecting thunderstorms in the Illawarra or Sydney metropolitan area tonight. Sydney weather radar Brisbane radar 
But Queensland hasn’t escaped the weather’s wrath with a current marine wind warnings along the Sunshine Coast waters and Gold Coast waters. 
Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Adam Blazak told the Brisbane Times a trough would move over southeast Queensland this afternoon. 
“We’re expecting it to start around the ranges south of Toowoomba and move quickly towards Brisbane to the sea,” he said. 
Brisbane is also set to be lashed by wild weather around 3pm today. 
The State Emergency Service has advised people in affected areas to move their cars away from trees, secure any loose items, and unplug non-essential appliances. Residents are also advised to avoid using their phones during storm events. 
The weather warnings follow on from storms lashing Sydney on Tuesday. 
Two women are recovering after being struck by lightning during the fierce thunderstorms that swept across the city. 
A woman, believed to be in her 20s, was hit by lightning in the inner-west suburb of Newtown around 6pm Tuesday and was taken to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital where she remains in a serious but stable condition. 
Another woman was struck at St Mary’s in Sydney’s west at 5pm, an ambulance spokeswoman said. 
She was taken to Nepean Hospital but was later discharged. 
SES said it received 30 calls for help overnight. 
For emergency help in floods and storms, ring the SES (NSW and ACT) on 132 500. NSW Satellite
